awd_titl_txt: Dynamics of transcriptional regulatory complexes: Mechanism and function
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will define a new mechanism for dynamic regulation of gene expression.  Turning a gene on or off is known to occur by assembly of a "regulatory protein machine" on the DNA near the gene.  Such machines are composed of gene-specific combinations of proteins that work as a unit to switch the gene on or off in particular cells in particular ways. Emerging results indicate that mechanisms have evolved to actively disassemble these machines, resulting in a dynamic process of machine building and breakdown. This project will investigate how the dynamics of these regulatory protein machines alters the expression patterns of specific genes. The study is important because gene expression patterns have long been thought to be specified solely by the makeup of the regulatory machines without considering the role played by dynamics of machine building and breakdown.  The results of this work will define factors involved in regulatory machinery dynamics and how they selectively modulate gene expression patterns. Notably, this research plan is integral to the career planning, development, and advancement to independence of an outstanding woman scientist, providing valuable experience in conceiving, executing and managing an original, impactful research program.

Focusing on the glucocorticoid receptor (GR), this project will test the hypothesis that transcriptional regulatory complex (TRC) dynamics is a determinant of specific gene expression. The steroid hormone cortisol, which gates GR activity, circulates at levels that fluctuate according to circadian and ultradian (~1 hour) cycles, and spike in response to certain external cues. DNA-bound GR-containing TRCs are highly dynamic in vivo, with disassembly driven by molecular chaperones. This project will 1) define mechanisms of GR:DNA dynamics; 2) identify factors that target chaperones to TRCs to confer disassembly; and 3) determine effects of TRC dynamics on GR-regulated transcription. Mechanisms will be pursued in vitro and in cultured cells using molecular biological, biochemical, and proteomic methods to define how chaperone-mediated dynamics confers specific transcription patterns in response to glucocorticoid fluctuations. Revealing dynamics as a regulatory modality will advance understanding of context-specific metazoan gene expression, the principle mechanism that distinguishes cells types and shapes biological processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to obtain a mechanistic understanding for an unexplored and potentially crucial aspect of one of the most essential and fundamental process in biology, gene regulation. Furthermore, this research was integral to career planning, development and advancement to independence of an early career woman scientist, providing valuable experience in conceiving, executing and managing an original, impactful research program.

Central to gene regulation is transcription, the processes by which DNA-encoded genes are “switched on” or expressed. While each cell contains a full set of DNA-encoded genes, specific genes are typically expressed only in particular cell types, at different levels, at specified times, and under certain conditions. Transcription is thus a highly regulated process with spatial and temporal precision in response to biological and environmental cues being orchestrated by the assembly of “regulatory protein machines” on specific regions of DNA close to a gene whose expression is controlled, i.e., a gene-specific combination of different proteins that work as a unit to switch the gene on or off in particular ways. Interestingly, mechanisms have evolved that actively and continually disassemble these machines, resulting in a dynamic process of machine building and breakdown. However, the prevailing view has been that gene expression patterns are specified solely by the particular components stably assembled into each regulatory machine, despite provocative evidence that theses regulatory complexes are highly dynamic, and that the dynamic properties themselves contribute to regulatory function.

In this work, two hypothetical models were explored that could account mechanistically for the rapid dynamics of these regulatory complexes and their functional contribution to gene regulatory outcomes: 1] the dynamics of the regulatory complexes enable a rapid and sensitive transcriptional response to changes in relevant signals, specifically sudden decreases in upstream activating signals,  and 2] subunit disassembly from the complex promotes progression along ordered assembly/disassembly pathways, in which the multi-subunit regulatory complexes are in fact composed of an ensemble of temporally defined functional subcomplexes.

This work utilized the glucocorticoid receptor (GR), primary component of a transcriptional regulatory system commonly viewed as a paradigm for metazoan gene regulation. GR is an essential human transcription regulatory factor that directly binds DNA and nucleates the assembly of regulatory complexes that control the expression of numerous cell and tissue specific target genes. Importantly, GR’s activity is strictly controlled by cognate small molecule ligands, glucocorticoids such as cortisol.  Gating of GR’s regulatory activity by a small signaling molecule enables a chemical signal circulating through the blood stream to trigger precise cell- and tissue-specific transcriptional responses throughout the body. Central to the success of this work was methodology measures the abundance of short-lived nascent transcriptional products (nascent RNA) as opposed to the commonly measured mature form (mRNA), whose life-time is typically dominated by its degradation rate instead of its production rate. This allowed for the approximate kinetics of active transcription of specific GR-regulated genes to be measured.

In exploring the first hypothesis, it was determined that the rate of the transcriptional response to a sudden decrease in GR’s activating ligand was in fact determined by the slower rate of GR:ligand dissociation, and not the faster rate of GR dissociation from the DNA-bound regulatory complex.  Thus, in this context, the rapid dynamics of the DNA-bound regulatory complexes does not determine the rate of the transcriptional response. However, in support of the second hypothesis, it was discovered that for all GR-upregulated genes investigated, in response to constant ligand concentrations, nascent RNA levels oscillate in a synchronized cyclical pattern. Importantly, these oscillations are not clearly observed by tracking mRNA. This indicates that in this context, transcription occurs in discrete pulses as opposed to a sustained and continuous production as previously thought and inferred through mRNA measurements.  Intriguingly, these repeated pulses in transcriptional activity are consistent with previous observations in a related transcriptional regulatory system (the estrogen receptor) that suggested sequential cyclical assembly and disassembly of specific regulatory complex subunits that in turn provoked the cyclical recruitment of the transcriptional machinery.  Together, this supports a mechanism in which an ordered assembly and disassembly pathway, which determines the assembly of specific functional subcomplexes, is deployed repeatedly to achieve a regulatory outcome. Importantly, during this process the dissociation of one subcomplex must occur to make room for the next subcomplex. Therefore, the repeated regulated GR dissociation could allow for efficient progression of this pathway by clearing “spent” or dead end subcomplexes to allow assembly of the next functional subcomplex. By starting to unify the unusual dynamic behaviors of transcription regulatory complexes with the dynamics in transcriptional outcomes under a mechanistic conceptual framework, this work helps advance our fundamental understanding of metazoan gene expression, the principle mechanism that shapes biological processes.
